column1: To my mind, it is clear that the Respondents had no inten(cid:415)on of allo(cid:427)ng shares to the
Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner although the Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner had invested USD 250,000 by 1995. It appears that the
Respondents could no longer resist calls from the Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner that eﬀect be given to the
commercial deal struck between them way back in 1994 and 1995 and that, as suggested
by the Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner, hurriedly prepared a series of documents, namely R3, R4 and R5 that
would allot the Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner the minimum possible number of shares and allot to themselves

shares 
in  excess  of  94%,  having  only  paid  Rs.  1.46  per  share.
Respondents commi(cid:425)ed a series of fundamental mistakes rela(cid:415)ng to the procedure that
should  have  been  followed  and  the  Respondents  now  ﬁnd  themselves
precarious posi(cid:415)on than they should be in. I can only agree with the submission of the
learned President’s Counsel for the Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner that the ac(cid:415)ons of the Respondents have
boomeranged on them in a manner in which it was least expected by the Respondents.
